thread.section_title: Latest business and finance news from New Zealand and the world's key markets - Yahoo New Zealand Finance
thread.title: Banks drag on market

title: Banks drag on market
text:
Print 
The Australian share market has opened almost half a per cent lower, with the big banks and energy stocks leading the falls. 
Shares in Australia's second biggest bank Westpac have been halted as it announces a $3.5 billion rights entitlement offering as well as a 0.2 per cent hike in its standard variable interest rate. 
Investors turned cool on the other three majors, sending Commonwealth Bank down 47 cents to $73.76 as ANZ fell 27.5 cents to $28.235 while National Australia Bank was off 12 cents to $31.11. 
"Westpac's announcement of capital placement clearly is going to dampen any enthusiasm for investment in banks in the short term at least while this issue is digested," CMC Markets chief market strategist Michael McCarthy says. 
He believes a lot of buying orders in the sector were cancelled today as a result. 
Meanwhile, energy stocks fell for a third session in a row, on the back of falling oil prices, with Santos shedding 24 cents, or 4.32 per cent, to $5.32 as Origin gave back 19 cents, or 3.2 per cent, to $5.74 and Woodside Petroleum descended 21 cents, or 0.67 per cent, to $31.15. 
Out of the big miners, Rio Tinto was in the black after its CEO Sam Walsh said he was not interested in bidding for troubled Swiss miner Glencore. 
Rio's shares were up 14 cents to $53.54, while BHP Billiton was down three cents to $24.78 following a two per cent fall on Tuesday. 
Treasury Wines was in a htrading alt at $6.54 after it announced it will by the US and UK based wine operations of drinks giant Diageo, while Dominos was up $2.02 to $41.79 after it announced it will acquire 89 Pizza Sprint stores in France. 
KEY FACTS 
* At 1015 AEDT on Wednesday, the benchmark S&P/ASX200 index was down 22.0 points, or 0.42 per cent, at 5,108.9 points. 
* The broader All Ordinaries index was down 19.9 points, or 0.38 per cent, at 5,214.7 points. 
* The December share price index futures contract was down 32 points at 5,159 points, with 8,408 contracts traded. 
* At 1058 aedt, National turnover was 403 million securities worth $835 million. @YahooNZBusiness on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Financial crime taskforce nets tax dodgers AAP
